vectorData.altText: 8. The attachment of a ligament or tendon to bone is called a(n) ________________.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

An enthesis is the area of attachment between tendon, ligament or joint capsule to bone. It functions to pass tensile forces from the soft tissue structure to bone, and distribute force through the bone, away from the point of attachment. This spares the point of attachment from bearing all applied forces.
Two types of entheses are described: fibrous and fibrocartilagenous. 
In fibrous (“indirect”) entheses, attachment occurs via periosteum with the mineralization of perforating collagen fibres. Fibrous entheses tend to occur where tendon attaches to the shaft of a bone, and therefore the angle between the tendon and bone does not change during contraction of the muscle. They are less prone to stress injuries. An example is the attachment of the deltoid muscle to the midshaft of the humerus.
In fibrocartilaginous (“direct”) entheses, attachment occurs via a transitional, fibrocartilagenous zone. They tend to occur at epiphyses or apophyses (tubercles) where the angle of attachment of the tendon to bone changes during muscular contraction. This puts stress on the enthesis. However, with normal use, the fibrocartilagenous intermediate zone permits some “give”, which allows the enthesis to accommodate the changing angle between the tendon and its insertion.
Examples of fibrocartilaginous entheses are the attachment of the rotator cuff muscles and that of the tendo calcaneus     . The majority of entheses are fibrocartilaginous; they are also more prone to overuse injuries than are fibrous entheses.
That's right! An enthesis is the area of attachment of a ligament or tendon to bone.
